triples.name: Explainable artificial intelligence
triples.relevance: The paper's core focus is designing explainable AI tools that provide understandable reasoning to legal experts.

triples.name: Legal reasoning
triples.relevance: The paper models legal reasoning processes to build decision-support tools for case analysis.

triples.name: European Court of Human Rights
triples.relevance: The paper uses actual cases from the European Court of Human Rights to develop and evaluate the tools.

triples.name: European Convention on Human Rights
triples.relevance: The paper specifically models Article 6 of the convention to create the legal domain framework.

triples.name: Argumentation theory
triples.relevance: The paper uses computational models of argument to construct the formal legal domain model.

triples.name: Decision support system
triples.relevance: The paper develops practical decision-support tools that help legal experts make case decisions.

triples.name: Formal methods
triples.relevance: The paper develops formal models of the legal domain to ensure precise reasoning.

triples.name: Legal expert system
triples.relevance: The paper creates AI-based tools that emulate expert legal decision-making abilities.

triples.name: Usability testing
triples.relevance: The paper conducts user studies to evaluate the usability and effectiveness of the tools.

triples.name: Trustworthy AI
triples.relevance: The paper demonstrates how trustworthy AI tools can be built with explainability grounded in legal reasoning.
